numeralsView.description: á€‚áá€¬á€”á€ºá€ášá€ºá€¹á€á€»á€¬á€™á€”á€ºá€á€¡á€ºá€‚á€¾á€º á€á€»á€°á€á€¯ášá€ºá€…á€±á€¬á€²á€œá€á€º á€™á€œá€­á€€á€ºá€áŸá€±ášá€º á€‡áŸá€¬á€•á€ºá€™á€‚áá€”á€ºá€›áŠ á€‚áá€¬á€”á€ºá€ášá€ºá€¹á€á€»á€¬á€™á€”á€ºá€á€¡á€ºá€‚á€¾á€ºá€á€¯á€•á€ºá€€á€µá€¯ á€™á€œá€­á€€á€ºá€¡á€­á€”á€ºá€’á€±á€«á€›á‹ á€™á€‚áá€”á€ºá€á€¡á€ºá€‚á€¾á€º á€€á€¹á€á€µá€¯á€’á€¾á€ºá€€á á€¯ášá€ºá€”á€°á€€á€µá€¯á€•á€¶ášá€ºá€•á€á€­á€¯á€”á€ºá€™á€‚áá€”á€ºá€á€¡á€ºá€‚á€¾á€ºá€›áŠ á€™á€‚áá€”á€ºá€á€¡á€ºá€‚á€¾á€ºá€—á€¾á€ºá€¡á€¬á€”á€°á€œá€¹á€•á€¬á€ºá€•á€«á€²á€…á€­á€¯á€•á€ºá€œá€¹á€•á€¬á€ºá€•á€¯ášá€ºá€›á‹ á€¥á€•á€™á€¬áŠ á€á€½á€€á€ºá€‚á€½á€¶á€—á€’á€¾á€º "á‚á‡" (27)á€‚á€¾á€º á€™á€‚áá€”á€ºá€ášá€ºá€¹á€á€»á€¬á€™á€”á€º á€™á€‚áá€”á€º "á‚" (2) á€‚á€¾á€ºá€•á€¶ášá€ºá€€á€µá€¯ á€™á€‚áá€”á€º "á‡" (7)á€›á‹ á€‚áá€”á€ºá€ášá€ºá€¹á€á€»á€¬á€‡áá€±á€¬á€ºá€‡áá€±á€¬á€ºá€œáŸá€­á€Ÿá€ºá€‚á á€­á€¯ášá€ºášá€ºá€á€¡á€ºá€œá€±á€á€º á€œáŸá€±á€¬á€á€ºá€—á€€á€ºá€¡á€¬ á€’áá€¬á€²á€á€¯á€•á€ºá€•á€ºá€€á€µá€¯ á€—á€®á€¯á€áá€±á€¬á€á€ºá€áá€±á€¬á€á€ºá€‚áá€”á€ºá€¡á€¬á€›á€¬á€•á€ºá€—á€±á€á€ºá€á€¡á€ºá€›á‹
numeralsView.description2: á€‚áá€”á€ºá€ášá€ºá€¹á€á€»á€¬á€™á€”á€ºá€á€¡á€ºá€‚á€¾á€º á€—á€½á€²á€™á€‚á á€­á€¯ášá€º á€á€¯ášá€ºá€…á€±á€¬á€²á€¡á€¬á€•á€¹á€á€² á€¡á€›á€¬á€•á€Šá€¬áŠ á€œá€­á€€á€ºá€•á€›á€±ášá€ºáŠ á€œá€­á€€á€ºá€•á€á€ºáŠ á€€á€¼á€€á€¹á€€á€’á€­á€”á€ºáŠ á€€á€±á€¯á€¬á€¶ á€¡á€á€­ášá€ºá€”á€¬á€á€³á€á€¡á€ºá€›á‹ á€›á€™á€»á€¬ášá€º á€€á€µá€¯ á€—á€®á€¯á€‚á€½á€¶á€—á€€á€•á€ºá€™á€œá€­á€€á€º á€‚áá€”á€ºá€ášá€ºá€¹á€á€»á€¬á€™á€”á€ºá€á€¡á€ºá€‚á€¾á€º á€áá€Ÿá€ºá€á€¼á€¬á€”á€° á€œá€­á€€á€ºá€—áŸá€¬ á€€á€±á€¯á€¬á€¶ á€œá€­á€€á€ºá€á€±á€¶á€›áŠ áœá€­á€¯á€”á€ºá€‚á€¾á€ºá€œá€±á€á€º á€Ÿá€­á€¯á€á€ºá€”á€°á€¡á€†á€€á€ºá€…á€•á€ºá€á€™á€ºá€›á€­á€¯á€Ÿá€ºá€›á€¬á€‡á€ášá€ºá€á€¯á€² á€—á€®á€¯á€•á€¼ášá€ºá€›á€¯á€•á€ºá€›á€´á€™á€‚áá€”á€ºá€á€¡á€ºá€‚á€¾á€º á€á€¯á€•á€ºá€á€´á€™á€¬á€”á€ºá€›á‹
numeralsView.integerExamples: Examples of Multi-Digit Integer á€¥á€•á€™á€¬á€…á€•á€ºá€€á€µá€¯ á€™á€‚áá€”á€ºá€•áŸá€á€º á€•á€±ášá€ºášá€º
numeralsView.decimalsDescription1: Historically, Mon numerals did not use a decimal separator at all. The decimal point (.) came into Burmese & Mon usage through Western mathematics and education during the British colonial period (1886â€“1948).
numeralsView.decimalsDescription2: Before that, Mon & Burmese mathematical texts (e.g., astrology, astronomy, and arithmetic treatises) used vulgar fractions rather than decimal fractions.
numeralsView.decimalsDescription3: Today, in Myanmar, people use the â€œ.â€ for decimals, just like internationally.
numeralsView.mathematicsDescription: Mon language mathematical equations use universal components but will be read of as follows:
numeralsView.timeDescription: Counting time in Mon is done by reading hours and minutes using Mon numerals and words specifically related to time. Both the 24-hour clock system and the 12-hour clock system display time as [hour]:[minute] followed by the word á€”á€¬á€á€³ (hour). For example, áƒ:áá… á€”á€¬á€á€³ means 3:15 a.m. or á€”á€°á€‚á€šá€¸ áƒ:áá… á€”á€¬á€á€³ means 3:15 a.m
numeralsView.timeDescription2: The traditional Mon timekeeping system uses a 6-hour system, dividing the day into sections such as dawn, morning, noon, afternoon, evening, night, and midnight.
numeralsView.calendarDescription1: This table provides an overview of how to read and use the calendar in Mon. The Gregorian calendar is commonly used, but traditional lunar months and different year systems are also recognized.
numeralsView.calendarDescription2: Dates are typically written in the format: day/month/year or dd/MM/yyyy. Refer to the tables below for month names, abbreviations, and year system conversions.
numeralsView.monthsDescription1: Below are the names of the months in Mon, Thai, and English, along with their abbreviations and the number of days in each month.
numeralsView.lunarCalendarDescription: The traditional lunar calendar is used for religious and cultural events, such as festivals, Buddhist holidays, and ceremonies. Each lunar month corresponds to specific occasions, and the calendar is especially important for determining the dates of traditional Mon and Thai celebrations.
numeralsView.yearsDescription: This section explains the different year systems used in Mon and neighboring cultures. The Christian Era (CE) is the international standard, while the Buddhist Era (BE) and Mon Era are used in religious and cultural contexts. Historical year systems based on kingdoms or significant events may also be encountered in old documents.
numeralsView.realmBasedDescription: This table lists historical year systems used in different Mon and neighboring realms. These systems were often based on the founding of kingdoms, dynasties, or significant historical events. This is not official, but we'd like to introduce them to you as a ceremonial to this great civilization.

getStartView.title: á€€á€™á€¼á€´á€œá€­á€€á€ºá€™á€”á€º
getStartView.getStartDescription1: The Mon alphabet represents a writing system of significant historical and typological interest in Southeast Asia. It is derived from the ancient Brahmi script lineage and has been instrumental in the transmission of TheravÄda Buddhist texts and Mon cultural heritage.
getStartView.getStartDescription2: The Mon alphabet is the writing system used for the Mon language, an Austroasiatic language spoken mainly in Myanmar (Burma) and Thailand by the Mon people.
getStartView.getStartDescription3: Itâ€™s historically important because Mon was one of the earliest languages in mainland Southeast Asia to be written down â€” and its script influenced the writing systems of neighboring languages, including Burmese, Thai, and Khmer.
getStartView.historyDescription1: The Mon language is one of the oldest languages still spoken in mainland Southeast Asia, with a history stretching back well over a millennium. It belongs to the Monic branch of the Austroasiatic language family, making it a relative of Khmer (Cambodian) and distantly related to Vietnamese and other languages in the region.
getStartView.historyDescription2: Unlike Thai, Burmese, or Chinese, the Mon language is a non-tonal language; meaning it does not use changes in the pitch of the voice to distinguish the meaning of a word.
getStartView.historyDescription3: Itâ€™s thought to have evolved from an ancient Austroasiatic proto-language spoken across much of mainland Southeast Asia thousands of years ago.
getStartView.scriptItem1: The Mon script is classified abugida, wherein each consonantal character inherently includes a vowel sound unless modified.
getStartView.scriptItem2: The writing direction is left to right, in horizontal rows.
getStartView.comparisonTitle: Comparison to Vietnamese, Khmer, Thai, and Burmese
getStartView.funFactItem1: Mon language, unlike Thai or Burmese, is a non-tonal language meaning changes in pitch (how high or low the voice is) do not change the meaning of a word.
getStartView.funFactItem2: According to Facebook page "à¹€à¸£à¸µà¸¢à¸™à¸ à¸²à¸©à¸²à¸¡à¸­à¸ Learning Mon Language", there are more than 2,000 Mon words that have influenced Thai words til this day.
getStartView.fontsDescription: Here are Unicode fonts for displaying Mon and Myanmar scripts correctly. If you see boxes or missing characters, please install one of these fonts to improve readability on your device.

pronounView.title: Pronouns (á€á€—á€¹á€—á€”á€¬á€¶)
pronounView.description: Pronouns are essential in communication as they are used to refer and replace nouns and help avoid repetition. In the Mon language, different pronoun forms can indicate respect, familiarity, gender, and social status. Choosing the correct pronoun variant is important, as it can affect the tone and meaning of a conversation, showing politeness or intimacy depending on the context.
pronounView.description2: Singular pronouns refer to one person, while plural pronouns refer to more than one. In Mon, plural pronouns often end with á€á€¡á€º to signify a group.
pronounView.firstPersonDescription: First person pronouns are used by the speaker to refer to themselves. In Mon, there are several forms depending on the level of formality, gender, and context. Choosing the appropriate form shows respect or familiarity in conversation.
pronounView.secondPersonDescription: Second person pronouns are used to address the listener directly. In Mon, the choice of pronoun depends on the level of formality, gender, and whether you are speaking to one person or a group. Using the correct form demonstrates politeness, respect, or familiarity in conversation.
pronounView.thirdPersonDescription: Third person pronouns are used to refer to someone or something other than the speaker or listener. In Mon, these pronouns vary based on gender, number (singular or plural), and the level of formality. Choosing the appropriate third person pronoun helps convey clarity and respect in communication.
pronounView.sameAgeOnly: Note: speak to people of the similar age only
pronounView.firstPersonReligiousDescription: In religious contexts, first person pronouns are used by the speaker (often a layperson or a monk) to refer to themselves with humility and respect. The choice of pronoun reflects the speaker's status and the formality of the situation, showing reverence in communication with monks or within religious ceremonies.
pronounView.secondPersonReligiousDescription: Second person pronouns in religious contexts are used to address monks, novices, or laypersons with appropriate respect. The pronoun chosen depends on the relative status of the speaker and listener, and helps convey politeness, reverence, or humility during religious discourse.
pronounView.thirdPersonReligiousDescription: Third person pronouns in religious contexts refer to individuals other than the speaker and listener, such as monks, novices, or laypersons. The form of the pronoun may change to show respect or indicate religious status, ensuring clarity and deference in religious conversations.
pronounView.firstPersonRoyalDescription: When speaking in royal contexts, first person pronouns are carefully chosen to express humility and acknowledge the speaker's lower status relative to royalty. These pronouns are used by subjects or officials when addressing or referring to themselves in the presence of a monarch.
pronounView.secondPersonRoyalDescription: Second person pronouns in royal contexts are used to address members of the royal family or monarchs with the utmost respect and formality. The pronoun selected reflects the high status of the listener and helps maintain proper etiquette in royal communication.
pronounView.thirdPersonRoyalDescription: Third person pronouns in royal contexts refer to royalty or other individuals in the presence of royalty. These pronouns are chosen to show respect and maintain the hierarchical structure of royal discourse, ensuring that references to royalty are appropriately formal and deferential.
pronounView.firstPersonPossessiveDescription: First person possessive pronouns are used by the speaker to indicate ownership or possession of something. In Mon, these pronouns refer to things that belong to the speaker (my, mine, our, ours). The form may change depending on whether the context is singular or plural, and the level of formality.
pronounView.secondPersonPossessiveDescription: Second person possessive pronouns are used to indicate that something belongs to the person or people being spoken to. In Mon, these pronouns correspond to 'your' or 'yours' in English. The form may change depending on whether you are addressing one person or a group, and the level of formality required by the context.
pronounView.thirdPersonPossessiveDescription: Third person possessive pronouns are used to show that something belongs to someone or something other than the speaker or listener. In Mon, these pronouns correspond to 'his', 'her', 'its', or 'their' in English. The choice of pronoun may vary based on gender, number, and formality.
pronounView.interrogativePronounDescription: Interrogative pronouns are used to ask questions about people or things. In Mon, these pronouns help form questions such as 'who', 'what', 'which', 'where', and 'why'. They are essential for gathering information and are commonly used in both spoken and written language.
pronounView.definitePronounDescription: Definite pronouns are used to refer to specific people or things that are already known or have been previously mentioned in the conversation. In Mon, definite pronouns help clarify exactly who or what is being talked about, leaving no ambiguity for the listener.
pronounView.indefinitePronounDescription: Indefinite pronouns are used to refer to non-specific people or things, such as 'someone', 'anyone', 'everyone', or 'something'. In Mon, these pronouns help express general statements or refer to unknown or unspecified entities. They are useful when the exact identity is not important or not known.
pronounView.distributivePronounDescription: Distributive pronouns are used to refer to members of a group separately, rather than collectively. In Mon, these pronouns express the idea of 'each', 'every', or 'either', and are used when talking about individuals within a group one at a time. They help emphasize individuality or distribution among the members.

keyboard.title: á€€á€±á€¬á€”á€ºá€á€±á€„á€º
keyboard.placeholder: Tap on the virtual keyboard to start

keyboardGuide.title: How to use Virtual Keyboard:
keyboardGuide.sect1Description: Please follow through each indicator as shown on the image above (Diagram #1) step-by-step from 1 to 5.
keyboardGuide.sect1No1: Keyboard layout: Comprised of interactive key buttons; each has its own Mon alphabet value. User can type any key on the keyboard layout to see the output on the text box.
keyboardGuide.sect1No2: Shift buttons: Positioned on the opposite side of each other; each works the same. When user press the button, the keyboard layout will display the rest of interactive buttons that also contain their own Mon alphabet values.
keyboardGuide.sect1No3: Text box: Used to display the text from user typing on the keyboard.
keyboardGuide.sect1No4: Copy text button: User can tap this button to copy the whole text from text box.
keyboardGuide.sect1No5: Keyboard switch buttons: In case if user wants to type in other languages. We are supporting the other 3 including English, Thai, and Burmese.
keyboardGuide.sect2Title: How a Mon word is constructed?
keyboardGuide.sect2Description: The image as shown above (Diagram #2) explains the alphabetical structure of how a single word can be constructed.
keyboardGuide.sect2Layer1No1: Consonant: the initial alphabet to type. Sometimes, a single consonant can be a completed word and pronounciation on its own.
keyboardGuide.sect2Layer1No2: Compound Consonant: (optional) the 2nd alphabet to type. However, if the word you are typing does not require a compound consonant, you can skip this part.
keyboardGuide.sect2Layer2No1: Vowel: (optional) the 3rd alphabet to type. However, if the word you are typing does not require a vowel alphabet, you can skip this part.
keyboardGuide.sect2Layer2No2: Final Consonant: (optional) the 4th alphabet to type. However, if the word you are typing does not require a final consonant, you can skip this part.
keyboardGuide.sect3Title: For example if we are to type a word
keyboardGuide.sect3Description: The image as shown above (Diagram #3) explains the construction of the word "á€€á€¼á€±á€¬á€•á€º" (adj. crips, n. roofing tile) by implementing the concept from Diagram #2.
keyboardGuide.sect4Title: Now do it yourselves, following these steps
keyboardGuide.sect4Description: See the image above (Diagram #4) and follow the steps below.
keyboardGuide.sect4No1: First, press on key "á€€" as the initial consonant.
keyboardGuide.sect4No2: Then, press on key "á€¼" to combine the compound consonant with the consonant.
keyboardGuide.sect4No3: Now, to add the vowel "á€±á€¬", press on key "á€±" first to make it shift to the start of the word.
keyboardGuide.sect4No4: So, we can press on key "á€¬" to complete the vowel orderly.
keyboardGuide.sect4No5: Next, press on key "á€•" to add the final consonant to the word. However, this is not a complete final consonant; as of right now, it is seen as single consonant with its own pronounciation.
keyboardGuide.sect4No6: To finish this, press on key "á€º" to mark the late final consonant as really final consonant. Thus, this word is completed.

textAnalyser.title: á€‰á€¬á€á€ºá€•á€á€±á€¬á€¶
textAnalyser.description2: To help you study the Mon language with latest technology. Trained with every grammatical rules. Simply, just type in any Mon word and it will analyse for you on; how to pronounce, and how to see syllable-by-syllable.
textAnalyser.noMeaning: No meaning found in our database
